30 30

Celebrating 30 Years of AIDS Vancouver

The 30 30 campaign was created in 2013 to celebrate AIDS Vancouverâ€™s 30th anniversary. The campaign pieces together the dynamic history of HIV in Vancouver, told by and for those who where there.

1986

1987

The First Funding

In 1987

  • The Simpsons cartoon first appears as a series of shorts on The Tracey Ullman Show. LINK
  • Canada introduces a one dollar coin, nicknamed the 'Loonie' LINK

Local

  • Vancouver holds its first AIDS Candlelight Memorial. LINK
  • The provincial government introduces Bill 34, a legislation that called for quarantining of people with AIDS. 'Quarantine Plan for AIDS'. LINK
  • AIDS Vancouver's first Executive Director, Bob Tivey is fired for statements he made without the AIDS Vancouver board's sanctioning. LINK
  • McLaren Housing is founded providing affordable housing for those affected with HIV/AIDS LINK

Statistics

  • 6 hemophiliacs in BC reported on having contracted HIV.
  • 524 HIV/AIDS Deaths in Canada. LINK
  • 1011 Canadians diagnosed with AIDS. LINK
  • 5 to 10 million estimated to be infected worldwide by the WHO. LINK

Global

  • AZT is approved by the US FDA for treatment of HIV/AIDS, at $10,000 per year, most expensive drug in history. LINK
  • US immigration bans people with HIV/AIDS. LINK
  • 'And the Band Played' written by Randy Shilts, is published. LINK
  • U.S. President Ronald Reagan for the first time publicly uses the word AIDS, five years after its discovery. LINK
  • Needle exchanges are first piloted in the UK. LINK

National

  • AZT becomes legally accessible in Canada. LINK
  • The Toronto People with AIDS Foundation (TPWAF) is formed. LINK
  • ACT Up's first protest March 24, 1987. LINK
1988

AIDS Vancouver - Prevent. Act. Support.
Celebrating 30 Years of AIDS Vancouver
  • 30th Anniversary RSVP
  • Donate
  • Acknowledgements

AIDS Vancouver plays a special role in providing quality health care to people affected by HIV/AIDS living in the Lower Mainland. It is clearly more than just a community health care organization. It is an organization whose presence and continued strength is essential to the quality for life of this community and of each individual and family who draws on its services.

Our Agency is a vital community asset which everyone affected by HIV/AIDS can share, and in which we all have a stake.

Visit us at aidsvancouver.org

2013 © AIDS Vancouver
